They are slightly different,

Vagrant is a local Development Environment Management Tool  , Docker is a distribution Management Tool , Virtual box is a Virtual Machine used in the Distribution layer also 

Vagrant create a very lightweight virtual machine boxes , for you to build your own local development environment , it's very very lightweight virtual machine , under the naming convention of Vagrant Box , it run headless (no Graphics ) with minimal requirements needed to run the required OS or Distribution and that's why , it's a very lightweight VM 

The main comparison between Virtual Box and Docker , is that the docker use what is called containers , which share the kernel , and differ between each container in the user management layer , in the Virtual Box , each VM has it's own Kernel  and it's own Operating System , so you 'll find yourself consuming more resources such as RAM , CPU Usage and Disk Storage in the case of the Virtual Machines

1- Docker containers share the same Kernel + Drivers + Hardware
Virtual Machines share the same Drivers + Hardware only, and each can have its own kernel.

So for example, you can run 2 VMs on the same host, one is Windows and the other is Linux.
But you can never 2 containers unless they are Linux containers compatible with the target Kernel of the host.

2- Docker containers does not need to boot, the kernel is already running, they just need to run the first User Mode process (init or systemd or netlogon or so)

These are the major two differences I think
ÙÙŠ Ø§Ù„ docker Ø§Ù†Øª Ù…Ø§Ø¹Ù†Ø¯ÙƒØ´ guest os Ø¨ÙƒÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙˆØ¯ Ø¨ØªØ§Ø¹Ù‡

Docker is lighter weight, meaning not the whole machine is virtualized, as the containers can share Kernel + drivers, it is a way of sandboxing a dev environment and in a production environment it is a way of sandboxing a deployment of an application. Being lighter weight your host can support more containers than VMs potentially and it is easier to share storage between containers and to set up communications between services hosted on containers. Having said all that, I am still struggling to get enough time to actually set it up on my machine with something useful :)

Here is what I think I understand in easier terms, and please correct me if I am wrong: with a virtual machine, you have your application + operating system. You can easily move your installation from one server to another, but you are also moving a whole copy of the operating system, and when you run the application, you are running both the host and virtual operating systems. Docker is like a virtual machine, but without the operating system. You get the same portability, with an application instead of a whole operating system.

Ahmed Badawy you don't need a course or a book, usually videos on youtube and the docker.com site will do it
https://docs.docker.com/linux/
There is also a windows and mac version

Many people talked about the technical details but not the use case. Docker containers are meant to be deployed to production, whereas Vagrant is not. This means that your development environment becomes exactly like production.

bos in a simple word: VM is a copy of OS, packages, virual hardware, CPU cycles and machine resources.

container: is a portable OS with the packages and softwares needed to run your app. 

w zai manta shayef kda el awalani day hya5od memory kteer fa7t fa msh hat2dr t run aktr mn VM m3a b3d laken el mwdoo3 m5talef shwya f mawdoo3 el containers. t2dar t run aktr mn 2 or 3 conrainer on the same server w msh ht7es b mshakel zai ma bt7sal m3a el VM

Docker introduced the idea of the container , which is a very light virtual machine ,a secured hosting environment for your applications, you'll feel that you are running your application on a complete Virtual machine ,and at the same time without consuming all the resources consumed from running more than one Virtual machine ,and without the license overhead of the Operating system , so less cost indeed as well , also bare in mind that , it's true the containers share resources like the kernel library and the drivers but they are totally isolated in the user management layer and application layer , so you could configure each container with different presetting

Also since this post is concerning devops , I recommend checking chef and/or puppet , which are an infrastructure as a code technology or tool , in other word , it's a configuration management tool embedded in a code , so that , you could always have a history of your configuration like git for coding , chef and puppets , serve well , when you have a lot of repetitive tasks that you need them to be stored , so that when you need to build or rebuild your infrastructure ,you can do it in few steps , also it's useful to have versioning for your infrastructure configuration management, so that if your current infrastructure configuration not suiting you well , you could always go to the version which best suit you , without doing everything manually
https://washraf.gitbooks.io/the-docker-ecosystem/content/Chapter%201/Section%201/What%20are%20Containers.html
